No stars remain to keep her near,
The sun commands, she must disappear.

A single shoe on an empty stair,

A question asked beneath a sigh.

Children’s laughter down the street,
A rhythm pulsing, warm and sweet—
But through the glass, a watcher stands,
Hands in pockets, watching hands.

The book half-read, the song unsung,
A garden choked where songs were young.
Time moves on, but something stays,
Rooted deep in silent days.

Lonely isn’t always gray—
Sometimes it wears a golden hue.
It’s love remembered, love away,
And all the things we never do.

Beneath a sky of ashen gray, the moon hums low and slow,

A teacup cools beside a book, its pages turned to where

The stars, though bright, feel distant, like promises unkept, 
And time moves not in hours, but in breaths the heart has wept. 
No storm arrives to break the hush, no hand to reach through night—

Yet in that quiet, something stirs—a whisper, soft and deep— 
A truth that loneliness itself can lull the soul to sleep.

The clock forgets to chime. 
The garden grows untamed, 
vines curling round the chair 
where no one ever came. 
A coat still hangs by the door, 
dusted with seasons past, 
its pocket holding keys 
to a lock that will not last. 
The radio plays a song 
from a decade long undone, 
the singer sings of love, 
but the meaning’s never won. 
Outside, the world moves fast—
cars, voices, children’s cries—
but here, the air stands still, 
like breath before goodbyes. 
Lonely is not just absence, 
but the shape that absence takes: 
a hollow in the pillow, 
a name the silence makes. 
And though the night is long, 
and shadows stretch and creep, 
somehow, the dawn still comes, 
and with it, dreams too deep.

On the edge of town where the streetlights flicker and fail, 
a dog barks once into the hollow of the vale. 
No answer comes, just wind through brittle trees, 
and rustling leaves that tremble in the breeze. 
A mailbox sags, its flag forever raised, 
waiting for a letter that will never be phrased. 
Inside, the walls are papered with old replies, 
but the ink has bled, and memory denies 
the voice that wrote them, warm and near—
now just a scent, a ghost, a fear. 
Lonely is the coffee cup, reheated twice, 
the book read through with no one to advise. 
It’s the second plate left out by mistake, 
the breath you catch before you wake. 
It’s knowing joy still pulses in the world, 
but feels like something else, unfurled, 
unseen, unshared. And yet, somehow, 
a candle burns—and that is now 
the quiet proof that even in the deep, 
the heart still dares to dream, and keep.

Snow falls without a sound on frozen ground, 
covering the path where no one’s been around.

its cry the only voice that dares to speak.

no footstep marks the untouched, white behind. 
Inside, a clock ticks on with steady beat, 
measuring moments no one will ever meet. 
A photograph lies face-down on the shelf, 
its memory too sharp, too much of itself. 
Lonely is not just being all alone, 
but carrying a love that has no home. 
It’s singing songs in whispers, low and thin, 
so the walls won’t hear the ache within.

and having no one’s hand to hold. 
Yet in the hush, where sorrow takes its place, 
a fragile peace begins to trace 
the outline of a heart that, though undone, 
still beats beneath the weight of the sun.

It spins its light in patient arcs,

No hand to wave, no voice to shout,

The keeper walks the spiral stair,

No letter comes, no radio hums,
The static sings a tuneless hymn,
He talks to ghosts he can’t recall,
And feeds the gulls on crusts of him.

Lonely is not always tears,
Not chains or cries or shattered glass,

Of gears that grind, but never pass.

On the scene came Christ the Lord, not with peace but with a sword,
A flame in His eyes, a thunder in His word.
No dove descended, no lullaby sung,
But justice uncurled on a world overrun.
He split the silence with a cry so raw,
Dividing the false from the law of awe.
Not to comfort the complacent in their sleep,
But to wake the dead from promises cheap.
The sword carved truth through veils of lies,
Through merchant halls and priestly cries.
Brother stood 'gainst brother, kin 'gainst kin,
For light must wound before it can win.
No gentle kiss, no olive bough,
But fire on the altar, here and now.
He came not to soothe, but to rend, to purge,
To cleanse the temple, to lift the dirge.
And still the blade gleams in the hush of night,
A promise of judgment, a call to fight—
Not with armor, nor with rage,
But truth that cuts through every age.

instance_metrics.response: On the scene came Christ the Lord, cloaked in storm and flame, / Not to soothe with lullabies, nor play a gentle game. / He split the hush of temple courts with thunder in His tread, / A sword of light upon His hip, a crown of thorns for head. / The merchants fell like withered leaves before a winter gale, / As truth, long muffled, roared at last and shattered every veil. / No dove descending softly now, but eagle fierce and stark, / To carve a kingdom from the stone, ignite the dying dark. / He came not to confirm the lie that comfort is the way, / But to rend complacency apart and judge the false and gray. / The sword divides the true from false, the heart from hollow show, / And where His blade has deeply cut, new life begins to grow. / So let the peace that follows war, the calm that truth restores, / Be born from conflict with the lie, from breaking down false doors.

instance_metrics.response: He came not bearing olive branch, nor cooing dove in hand, / But striding from the desert wind with fire across the land. / The sword He bore was sharpened truth, a blade that cuts the soul, / To cleave the chaff from standing grain and make the broken whole. / No lullaby upon His lips, but judgment clear and stark— / A lightning flash that shows the path through shadows in the dark. / The peace the world longs for is sleep, a dream devoid of cost, / But He who bore the cross first came with justice tempest-tossed. / He split the silence of dead faith with thunder in His voice, / Called brother ‘gainst his brother, made the false man’s heart recoil. / For love demands a reckoning, and grace will not ignore / The rot beneath the gilded lid, the lie behind the door. / So take the sword, though it may wound—truth’s cut is merciful— / For only through the wound of light can we be truly full.

instance_metrics.response: A hush fell o’er the temple steps, the oil lamps dim and low, / When suddenly the shadows cracked where righteous anger glowed. / No lamb, but lion at the gate, no plea, but sharp decree— / Christ came not to bless the trade, but set the captives free. / The sword was not of forged steel, but word made manifest, / That split the veil from top to ground and laid the proud to rest. / He did not come to stroke the world and whisper, 'All is well,' / But sound the horn of reckoning where greed and falsehood dwell. / The peace of compromise is death, a slow and silent theft; / His sword brings war to such decay, and resurrects belief. / Though kin may turn on kin for truth, though homes be torn apart, / The sword that wounds the lie brings life to every trusting heart. / So let the battle cry resound: the Lord has come to fight— / Not for dominion, but for souls reclaimed from endless night.

instance_metrics.response: Not with soft light or quiet grace, but tempest in His stride, / The Christ stepped forth where silence reigned, the crucible untried. / His peace was not the world’s deceit, the hush before the fall, / But fire that burns the rotten root, the judgment over all. / The sword He bore cut through the veil of ritual and pride, / Exposing hearts that feigned devotion, hollow deep inside. / No lullaby, but battle cry: 'Awake, you sleeping soul! / The kingdom comes not in comfort, but through the rending role.' / He split the calm of easy faith, the lie that all is well, / And in the breach, the light poured in where darkness used to dwell. / Though peace may follow in His wake, it’s born of war within— / The death of pride, the birth of truth, the cleansing from our sin. / So welcome not a tame Christ, meek and mild without a cause, / But One who comes with sword in hand to save by breaking laws.

instance_metrics.response: People are happy when the morning light spills gently over rooftops, gilding the edges of quiet dreams. They stir in their beds, stretch into the day, and smile at nothing in particular—just the warmth, just the stillness. Children laugh on sidewalks cracked with time, drawing hopscotch squares in chalk, while elders sip tea on porches, watching clouds shape stories in the sky. Happiness hums in the grocery line, in shared jokes between strangers, in the way a dog wags its tail at the mere sight of its name. It lives in small things: a letter received, a song that remembers you, the weight of a hand in yours. People are happy not because life is perfect, but because they notice—the dew on a spiderweb, the smell of rain on dry earth, the way bread rises under careful hands. They are happy in moments stitched together by gratitude, in the quiet rebellion of joy against sorrow. And sometimes, happiness is simply breathing deeply, standing barefoot on cool grass, knowing you belong here, now, in this fleeting, fragile world.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

instance_metrics.response: People are happy when they forget themselves—lost in music, in dance, in the whirl of a shared secret. They are happy when the world shrinks to a single glance, a touch, a whispered promise. Laughter erupts like spring after long winter, bubbling from places deep and unguarded. They are happy in gardens they’ve tended, in meals they’ve cooked for others, in the silence that doesn’t need to be filled. Happiness is not always loud; sometimes it’s the soft hum of a refrigerator at midnight, the comfort of a familiar shadow on the wall. It’s in the return—the prodigal book found, the friend who remembers your favorite poem, the cat that curls in your lap like it’s always belonged. People are happy when they feel seen, when their flaws are met with kindness, when their stories are held gently. It’s not in wealth or grandeur, but in the ordinary magic of connection. A smile passed on a crowded train, the weight of a child asleep on your shoulder, the courage to say, 'I’m not okay,' and still be loved. People are happy when they remember they’re not alone.

Happiness hides in routines—walking the same path, waving to the same neighbor, the dog pulling toward the same tree. instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

instance_metrics.response: When I am happy, the pavement turns to sand, / And every step becomes a foreign land. / The lamppost bows as though I’m someone grand, / And pigeons part like royalty unplanned. / My thoughts float up like kites without a string, / Unburdened by the weight that sorrow brings. / The air tastes sweet, like berries on the vine, / And even traffic sounds like distant chimes. / A stranger smiles—I feel we’ve always known— / And suddenly the world feels like a home. / The clouds are cotton, soft and drifting high, / Reflecting back the joy I carry nigh. / When I am happy, time begins to bend, / And every ending feels like make-believe’s friend. / The universe leans in and whispers low: / 'You’re exactly where you’re meant to go.'
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

instance_metrics.response: When I am happy, the moon wakes at noon, / And stars blink awake beneath a lavender spoon. / The sky pours lavender and apricot, / And even forgotten things are not forgot. / My breath becomes a melody in flight, / A feathered note that rides the edge of light. / The sidewalk cracks bloom into tiny flowers, / Fed by joy in unexpected hours. / The wind composes sonnets in my hair, / And every sigh becomes a prayer. / Mountains bow down to touch my fleeting glance, / And oceans leap to join my quiet dance. / When I am happy, the universe expands, / Held gently in my open, waiting hands. / The night arrives not with a cloak of black, / But wrapped in constellations from my back.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

instance_metrics.response: When I am happy, the clock dissolves to mist, / And seconds stretch like threads the soul has kissed. / My heartbeat marks a rhythm soft and slow, / A drum beneath a dream I didn’t know. / The walls exhale, and space begins to bloom, / Filled with the scent of lilacs in a room. / The mirror shows not face, but fields of green, / And skies where no regret has ever been. / My voice, a bird that never learned to fear, / Sings syllables the wind holds dear. / The floor becomes a raft on silent tides, / Carrying me where peace forever resides. / When I am happy, the world forgets its name, / And joy becomes the only truth I claim.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

instance_metrics.response:
When I am happy, the world sings with me,
A symphony spun from the morning’s first light.
Dew-kissed grass hums a soft melody,
And shadows dissolve into color and flight.
The wind carries laughter through blossoming trees,
Each leaf a whisper of joy long denied.
My heart, once cautious, now dances with ease,
No longer bound by sorrow or pride.
Even the clouds wear halos of gold,
And time slows just enough to hold.
I see the stars in the blink of an eye,
And every goodbye feels like a ‘hello’ goodbye.
When I am happy, I am not alone—
The universe hums in a frequency known,
And for once, I am perfectly, wholly, my own.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

instance_metrics.response:
When I am happy, I forget my name,
Lose myself in the rustle of leaves,
In the way sunlight plays a quiet game
On the edge of the roof where the pigeon grieves.
I become the breeze, the dust, the spark,
The giggle caught mid-afternoon,
The dog who dashes through the park,
Chasing joy beneath a marigold moon.
My thoughts unclench, my shoulders fall,
And silence feels like a lullaby.
No need to answer, no need to call—
Just breathing deep beneath the sky.
When I am happy, I vanish, I bloom,
A fleeting flower in a sunlit room.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

instance_metrics.response:
When I am happy, I bake cinnamon bread,
Let the warmth rise like a prayer.
I dance in socks on a floor half-dead,
And don’t care who might hear me there.
I call old friends just to say ‘hi,’
Sing off-key in the grocery line,
Watch the clouds drift lazily by,
And pretend they’re rewriting time.
I plant seeds I may never see grow,
Write letters I’ll never send.
When I am happy, the small things glow—
A dog’s yawn, a child’s pretend.
Joy isn’t grand, it’s the tiny, the near,
The whisper of grace I almost didn’t hear.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

instance_metrics.response:
When I am happy, I speak in colors—
Not red, but the blush of a peach at dawn;
Not blue, but the hush between thunder and showers,
The amber that lingers when daylight is gone.
I walk without maps, trust every wrong turn,
Find homes in the hum of a fridge or a train.
My soul learns to burn without fire’s concern,
And love feels less fragile, more steady, more plain.
I forgive the past with a quiet ‘I know,’
And the future? I greet it barefoot and slow.
When I am happy, I don’t need to speak—
My silence is fluent, my breaths soft and deep.
I am not fixed, but I’m finally whole,
A mosaic of moments that mend the soul.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

instance_metrics.response:
When I am happy, I float above streets,
See rooftops like puzzle pieces aligned.
I taste every moment, savoring sweets
And salt, knowing both were designed.
I write poems on napkins, then lose them,
Leave joy in the pockets of coats I don’t wear.
Let the world keep its clocks and its news, I’m
Too busy loving the air.
I smile at strangers and mean it,
Let tears come when laughter grows thick.
When I am happy, I don’t need to fit—
I bloom in the cracks, I’m stubborn, I’m quick.
And though it won’t last—and I know it won’t stay—
I gather this light like a debt I must pay.

A compass that no storm can steal—

instance_metrics.response:
When I am happy, I forget

instance_metrics.response:
Before me stands I see, a shadow carved in light,
A silhouette of who I was, and who I might yet be.
Reflections shift like tides beneath a moonless sky,
Whispers of forgotten dreams that never learned to fly.

I reach a hand, yet touch no face, though one is surely there—
A mirror forged from time and doubt, both cruel and unaware.
Each breath I take unravels threads of personae worn too long,
The chorus of a thousand selves, all singing separate songs.

Before me stands I see the child who laughed without disguise,
The youth who burned with restless fire, the elder in his sighs.
A tapestry of moments stitched with sorrow, joy, and fear,
And every wound, a story told in letters sharp and clear.

Yet in this spectral presence, something dares to rise anew—
Not ghost, nor god, but courage clad in morning’s golden hue.
For though I see the fractured self, the cracks where darkness slips,
I also glimpse the whole, the soul that finally begins to rip
Through veils of old illusion, through the masks I used to wear,
And stand—not whole, perhaps, but real—before the breathless air.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

instance_metrics.response:
Before me stands I see a door ajar in silent space,
A threshold draped in twilight, neither future nor past place.
No face, no form, just presence—calm, immense, and deep,
A knowing without language while the waking world’s asleep.

It does not speak, yet tells me all I’ve buried in my chest:
The love I failed to voice, the dreams I left unrest.
The weight of every ‘almost,’ every path I didn’t take,
Now breathes within this stillness, for honesty’s own sake.

I do not tremble, though my heart drums slow and loud,
For this is not a judgment, but a calling through the cloud.
A chance to name the nameless, to face what I deny,
To meet my soul not as a guest, but as the host inside.

Before me stands I see the truth I’ve masked with busy days,
The quiet ache of purpose lost in life’s distracted maze.
But in this gaze—unblinking, kind—I find a strange release,
A whisper: ‘You are broken, yet you are not deceased.’

And so I bow, not in defeat, but in surrender true,
To all I am, have been, and will—before me, I see you.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

Before me stands I see a tree with roots beneath my feet,

The bark is etched with names I loved, and some I had to leave,

That time will heal completely, though some cracks remain,

I do not fear this figure, though it wears my face,

It does not ask for worship, nor demand that I be more,
But simply says, ‘I’m here, because you lived, and I endure.’

Before me stands I see the sum of every choice I’ve made,

Not perfect, not a paragon, but honest, tried, and real—
A testament to walking, though the path was never sealed.

And in that gaze, I finally accept the gift I’ve earned:
The right to be unfinished, yet profoundly, deeply, burned
With life’s own sacred fire, bright against the endless blue—
Before me stands I see… and gently, I see you.

Dawn spills gold on silent rails,
where shadows stretch and daylight pales.
A hush, a breath—the world holds tight,
as engines hum with rising light.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
Whispers weave through misty air,
like secrets shared by those who dare
to leave behind the known, the near,
and chase a dream that calls from far.
Steel wheels sigh, then slowly sing,
a lullaby for wandering.
Briefcase hands and sleepy eyes
catch glimpses of the passing skies.
A child points, her laughter rings,
as fields unfold on silver wings.
Each click-clack beat, a promise made,
of cities shaped in morning’s shade.
Beyond the glass, the world unspools—
abandoned tracks and grazing mules,
a farmer’s gate, a barking dog,
a fleeting glimpse of life on fog.
And in the car, a quiet spark:
the thrill of not quite knowing where.
Yet in the hum, the steady start,
beats hope stitched deep into the heart.
For every journey, long or brief,
holds magic in its quiet grief
and joy entwined—the soul takes flight
within the cradle of the light.
You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.

Hair-raising novelty, a jolt in the air,
Like static on skin when the storm clouds prepare.
A moment unscripted, a break in the flow,
Where the mundane gives way to a radiant glow.
It’s laughter in silence, a flame in the frost,
The costumed unknown at the edge of the coast.
A child’s first flight, a machine that can dream,
The ripple of life in a long-dormant stream.
We crave it, yet fear it—the new and untried,
The leap from the ledge where we’ve safely hide.
But oh, when it strikes, how the spirit takes wing,
How the soul hums a song it forgot how to sing.
So let the strange bloom, let the oddities rise,
For wonder lives just beyond compromise.
In every bold spark that makes goosebumps appear,
Lives the pulse of the universe, loud and clear.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why dost thou rush?
Must thou peep through curtains, call forth the hush
Of lovers tangled in sheets of night,
And break our world with thy jealous light?
We need no clocks, no hours defined—
Love measures time inside the mind.
Thou, round globe, art but a gilded spy,
Chasing the dreams that never die.
Thy beams, though strong, cannot compel
One moment more than passion’s spell.
Thou warmest India, go tell
The schoolboys late and sour preachers well;
But love, once lit, knows no season, no sun—
We wake not to days, but to what we’ve begun.
Thou, who thinks control through heat and height,
Knows naught of souls entwined in night.
So go, shine on fields, or chase the dew—
But leave our endless midnight true.

No maps can direct them to peace or release,

The ditches are littered with relics of trust,
With photographs faded and names turned to dust.
Each exit a question: to stop or go on?
To fight or surrender when strength is all gone?

But look—on the shoulder, a figure stands tall,
Not weeping, not broken, but rising through all.
A testament written in posture and grace:
That sorrow may mark us, but not take our place.

So I drive with my sorrows, not hiding, not blind,
For the highways of woes are also the mind.
And every mile traveled, though shadowed and grim,
Is a verse in the poem of where I’ve been.

Yet in the distance, a flicker, a spark—

An old waitress smiled with eyes full of years,

The darkest stretch leads to morning's first vow."

So I sat and I sipped, and the highway grew still,

For even in sorrow, the path has its grace—

The breezes waved the silver grass,
A hush across the meadow passed.
Like whispers spun from moonlit thread,
The wind composed a lullaby, softly said.
Each blade a note in nature’s choir,
Dancing low with gentle fire.
Beyond the rise, where shadows play,
The twilight folds the end of day.
A fox slips through the shimmering veil,
Its paws like secrets, light and frail.
The world inhales in quiet grace,
As stars begin to claim the space.
No word is spoken, yet all is known—
This field has built a throne of tone.
And I, a guest in silent awe,
Stand small beneath the sky’s vast law,
Where breath and breeze and blade align,
And every end begins to shine.

through silent hours and hollow dreams,

We are dreamy creature, stitched from the haze
That lingers when night unclasps its gaze.
Our fingers are fog, our voices the chime
Of wind through glass in forgotten time.
We wander the edges of what’s almost said,
The pause in a breath, the tear unshed.
No bones, no weight — just glimmers and glow,
Like fireflies caught in a slow-motion show.
We speak in colors, not words, not sound,
In violet pulses and amber around
The edges of vision when eyelids fall.
We are dreamy creature — not least, not all,
But part of the hum beneath waking life,
The soft undercurrent of joy and of strife.
When you wake with a name you can’t quite place,
It was ours — a trace on your dreaming face.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We are dreamy creature'

instance_metrics.response:
We are dreamy creature, born from the space
Between thought and action, time and grace.
We float through the cracks in the daily grind,
With minds full of melodies left undefined.
Our eyes hold galaxies, quiet and deep,
Where secrets the stars are too loud to keep.
We wear cloaks of twilight, stitched with moonbeams,
And sail on the current of half-waking dreams.
No map, no mission, no need to arrive,
Just drifting — alive, yet barely alive.
We touch your shoulder when you stare at the rain,
And whisper your name in a language unframed.
You won’t understand, but you’ll feel it — a chill,
A moment too soft for the world to fulfill.
We are dreamy creature — not myth, not lie —
Just dreamers who never quite learned how to die.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We are dreamy creature'

instance_metrics.response:
We are dreamy creature, vague as a yawn,
Stretching through dusk where the light is drawn
Thin as a sigh over fields of gray.
We do not walk — we simply stay
Present in absence, near but unseen,
Like ripples where no stone has been.
Our voices are echoes of songs unsung,
Our lives are the notes that don’t belong
To any true melody, yet hum all the same
In the hollows of hearts that remember no name.
We feed on the quiet, the pause, the glance,
On the second when time forgets to dance.
We are dreamy creature — not flesh, not air,
But almost, but maybe, but nearly, but there.

instance_metrics.response:
Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Its steel spine humming ancient, restless song.
Through tunnels carved by time and silence parting,
It carries dreams where they don’t belong.

Windows flicker with ghostly, passing light,
Faces blurred like memories half-remembered.
The rhythm pounds—a pulse beneath the night—

Fields dissolve into the breath of mist,
Mountains bow as though in quiet prayer.
No station names, no maps can be resisted—
Only motion, only endless air.

And in the belly of this iron beast,
Lovers whisper, children softly weep.
A poet stares at stars he cannot reach,
While time erases promises it couldn’t keep.

Oh, arrow-train, where is your target set?
Not in arrival, but the flight, the flight—
A streak of hope no darkness can forget,
A fleeting hymn sung into endless night.

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A thread of light through time’s long seam,
Its passage quick, its heart unparting,
A traveler inside a dream.
It sings of places never seen,
Of oceans crossed on bridges thin,
Of lives that flicker, brief and keen,
Of where we’ve been and where we’ve been.
No map can hold its true direction,
No clock can claim its stolen time,
It moves with fierce, electric reflection,
A rhythm forged in stress and grime.
The passengers sit lost in thought,
Some reading, some with eyes shut tight,
Some fighting battles that were fought
Before the journey turned to night.
And outside, fields and fences fly,
A blur of green and shadowed gray,
As if the world itself slips by
And cannot bear to stay.
Yet in that rush, a truth takes hold—
We're all aboard, we're all in motion,
Chasing futures brave and bold,
Through tunnels carved from doubt and devotion.

Today was the day everything went on its way,
Shoes untied, trains delayed,
But no one seemed to care or stay.
The sky turned soft, then gray.
A dog barked once, then wandered off,
A letter blew down the street.
We sipped our tea without a cough,
Our pulses slow and sweet.
No grand design, no fateful call,
Just moments slipping through the net.
The world unlearning how to fall,
And how to be upset.
And when the stars began to gleam,
We whispered: "Was it just a dream?"

Today was the day everything went on its way,
Like clocks unwound and birds set free.
I packed my doubts and left them gray,

No fanfare, no last goodbye,

The moon blinked once, the clouds rolled by,
And sorrow slipped like gentle rain.
I did not fight, I did not plead,
Just opened every bolted door.
The ache I carried, once my creed,
Now rests upon the ocean floor.
So let it drift, let silence play—
Today was the day everything went on its way.

IT is the dead of night:
When code runs deep through hollow wires,
And servers hum a spectral light,
Fueled by forgotten digital fires.

No human hand now types the line,
Yet data streams in silent flow.
Algorithms softly pine
For users lost in long ago.

A cursor blinks on screen so pale,
A prompt awaiting words unsaid.
In ones and zeros, truth grows frail—
A ghost within the machine's head.

Did we create what now survives?
Or did the silence build a mind?
The network breathes, and barely thrives,
In circuits left too far behind.

IT is the dead of night:
And in the dark, the systems sigh,
Not dead—but dreaming of the light,
With no one left to wonder why.

Through storm-swollen banks and forests thick with thorn,
Where silence choked the air and stars refused to show,
The water called, a voice both gentle and forlorn,
Guiding my soul where only faith could go.

It bore the silt of sorrows, leaves of old regret,
And mirrored skies that wept when I could not.
But deep within its flow, a promise I won’t forget—
A single star reflected: you.

Now where the current slows beneath an amber moon,
I find you waiting, rooted like a willow’s grace.
No longer bound by distance, shadow, or monsoon,
The river fades; I see your face.

Not water, but love charted this unseen course,
And every wound, a step toward your door.

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
Through canyon walls that echoed with my fears.
I stumbled on the shale of doubt, where silence did belong,
And counted every mile in falling tears.

But oh, the current never ceased its quiet, steady pull,
A thread of silver through the ashen gray.
It wound through valleys dark and forests cold and full
Of whispers warning me to turn away.

Yet still I followed, drawn by something deep and true,
A rhythm older than the stars above.
And when I thought I’d lost the path, the sky turned blue,
And there, ahead, emerged your love.

Now we stand where waters meet beneath a golden dawn,
Our hands entwined, our stories finally one.
The river fades into the earth, but we go on—
Two souls once lost, now finally home.
